messages: 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:14): does anyone have a good reason why <u> is more appropriate than <mark> for indicating spelling errors, other than default rendering?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:23): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: it's the same reason why <dfn> is more appropriate than <cite> for indicating definitions

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I‚Äôd guess you mean more specific, except that <cite> doesn‚Äôt seem appropriate for definitions :) for me the semantics seem a little closer in that case
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:25): (that case = spell checker)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:25): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: <mark> is as appropriate for spelling mistakes as <cite> is for definitions :-)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:26): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: <mark>'s definition is "a run of text in one document marked or highlighted for reference purposes, due to its relevance in another context"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:26): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: unless you're specifically talking about the spelling mistakes, that definition doesn't have anything to do with spelling
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: for me highlighting and annotating were closer, but I can see <u> is more appropriate

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:29): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: while you‚Äôre around, CJK etc languages with non-western name order sometimes indicate the family name via capitalisation, underline or aside. would you say <u> would be appropriate for e.g. hcard, restyled to text-transform:uppercase?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:29): sure
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:30): that usage isn‚Äôt so popular, eg. Wikipedia has an aside, but I‚Äôve seen it used for Japanese names before
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:30): an aside?
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:31): well, a note above the article‚Äôs introduction stating the name order and which word is the family name
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:31): ah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:31): weird
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:32): eg: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mao starts with ‚ÄúThis is a Chinese name; the family name is Mao‚Äù
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:33): well, capitalising etc could be perceived as western imperialism as western names don‚Äôt get that treatment :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:42): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: oh, well, no markup is necessary in the case of the wikipedia convention
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:42): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: certainly i wouldn't expect <u> to be used. <aside> maybe.
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:43): true, true. but good to know <u> works for cases when the family name is directly indicated (as hcard needs wrapper elements anyhow)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:46): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: yeah, <u> is perfect for that. <u> is for when you are annotating something, but not explicitly saying what it is.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:47): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: i.e. where the annotation's meaning is implied by context

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:48): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yup :) just checking I understand before publishing. playing it safe after getting a little burned on <footer> in <blockquote> :D
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:49): didn‚Äôt know about proper name marks either ‚Äî interesting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:50): 1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f: heh, understood!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:51): Dammit, focus'd the wrong window.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:51): Well, that OTP expires in a few seconds.

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:52): hey 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, why is text-decoration specced as ‚ÄúValue: <text-decoration-line> || <text-decoration-color> || <text-decoration-style>‚Äù, not line, style then color (which would be more in keeping with border)?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:53): I have no idea.  The ordering is insignificant, though.

1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:54): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I (now) know that, but I suspect ppl who don‚Äôt understand || won‚Äôt realise that. I couldn‚Äôt find || in the CSS syntax doc btw
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:54): might email www-style about it‚Ä¶
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:54): Syntax is wildly out of date (I have a note on my whiteboard to volunteer to put a big "THIS IS OBSOLETE STOP LOOKING AT IT" marker on several specs).
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:54): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, is the ordering still insignificant wrt CSSOM serialization?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:54): It's explained in 2.1, though.
1e10d84b3917ae58049be95b0071cf7f (20:55): everything in TR? [ducks]
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:55): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: Nobody follows CSSOM serialization so far.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:55): Or at least, that part of it.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:56): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, nobody follows any spec, as a first approximation ;)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:57): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: "Doesn't exactly match every single detail" and "completely ignores" are pretty different.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:57): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: the ordering isn't insignificant, it impacts serialisation
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: See above conversation.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:58): i was still reading :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:58): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: they certainly won't implement it while the order is treated as insignificant in the specs :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:58): at least not interoperably :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:03): any opinions on http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=13174#c2 ?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:03): it seems a bit dubious to me, but i can't quite work out what i'd suggest instead
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:04): The example in #7 seems reasonable.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:07): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: you around?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:07): #7 is the real-world instance of #2
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:07): Yes, I know.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:07): my concern is that people will start putting all kinds of shit in <th>, like <hx>, <article>s, etc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:08): but i agree that that specific example seems like the least bad way of marking up that semantic
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:08): i guess i could explicitly only allow non-sectioning, non-heading content or something
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:08): Just put an example in, explaining what not to do?  Specifically, the spec could probably do with some text about Aryeh's example.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:08): yeah, maybe being explicit in an example is enough?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:13): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: see webapps

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: can you help me interpret HTML5 7.6.5, second ordered list, 4.1-2 (http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/dnd.html#drag-and-drop-processing-model)?
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:36): (or anybody else that's well versed with this spec.)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:36): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780, give me a link to the whatwg version and I can try :)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:37): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/dnd.html#drag-and-drop-processing-model
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:39): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: my question is simply, "If there will be a 'drop' event, should it *have* to complete before a 'dragend'?"
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:41): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: it sure seems to be implied that it's a "yes"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:51): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: what do you mean by "complete"?
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: should a "drop" event fire and be synchronously executed and completed before a "dragend" event is fired?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:53): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I can't find the CSSValue interface defined anywhere in CSSOM.  Am I missing something?

8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:55): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, I assume he means the CSS*Value interfaces at http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom/Overview.html#the-csspropertyvalue-interface and later
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:56): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: Well, 6.6.4 and 6.6.5 have things specifically returning a CSSValue.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: unless one of the event handlers dispatches its own event, event dispatch is always entirely synchronous within a task

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:58): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Maybe you mean CSSComponentValue there, and for the other types like CSSStringComponentValue to inherit from CSSComponentValue?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:58): I assume it'll be a superclass, then
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:59): Yeah, for now I'm just going to ape what CSSOM is doing.
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (22:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yes, that was my understanding as well, but check your PM
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): yeah i looked at that
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (22:08): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81, 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: thank you for your help
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:17): wonders what c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 is on about
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:18): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, what is the context you are talking about?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:18): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, nothing inherits from each other and nothing is exposed to prevent code from depending on specifics that can later be changed (if we change e.g. what value a property takes)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:19): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, basically a given property will return an object that implements several CSS value related interfaces
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:19): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, thanks for the email, hopefully hsivonen will look into it

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:24): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Hm, okay.  Well, I'm trying to define what I assume will be CSSVariableComponentValue.  If it doesn't inherit from CSSComponentValue, it needs to expose a .value by itself?
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (22:41): AryehGregor: if you're specing selection behavior, please make sure to spec selectstart event as well
3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (22:41): AryehGregor: in particular, bugs like https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=66948 are interesting to follow
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:43): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, no, all properties accepting <variable> would simply implement CSSVariableComponentValue as well
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:44): I looked again at CSSOM today and yesterday and wondered what I would need to change, but I still think the current model is sensible
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:44): Yes, but CSSVariableComponentValue itself has a name and a value.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:44): The problem is I guess that it's a) difficult and b) not implemented yet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:45): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, ah yeah, you would have to name them variableName and variableValue
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:45): sweet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:45): gonna get some cocktails now :)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:45): I'll ping you for review on this stuff later.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:46): great
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:46): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what do you mean?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:46): Drink a cocktail for me!
c480405f460f7a61964569640a6cd059 (22:47): heads out to lunch
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:58): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-css-wg/2011JulSep/0297.html
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:58): For your enjoyment
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:59): Btw, the correct answer is "Make the change you want to the template without asking anyone, because everyone's crazy."
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:00): My mistake there.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:00): "everyone's crazy."
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:00): I could have told you that :)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:02): If I define a getter in idl, do I just define the meaning of it in prose?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:02): Also: I don't understand what makes "creator" different from "setter".
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:03): creator is when the property doesn't exist yet, setter is when it does
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:03): I suspected as much, but wasn't sure.
